snippet.textDisplay:
Super interesting!

But... How can we test the hypothesis that there are multiple worlds with an experiment? Has that even been done? Or is this choice (Copenhagen or Many worlds interpretation) just a matter of aesthetics, i.e. which interpretation suits you better?

PS: If you stop to think about it, on either interpretation, the measurement depends on your actual conscience. In the Copenhagen interpretation, you "modify" the wave function by measuring it, but on the Many Worlds interpretation, once you know the measurement, you know exactly in which universe you are, so you "modified" or "collapsed" your universe.
snippet.textOriginal:
Super interesting!

But... How can we test the hypothesis that there are multiple worlds with an experiment? Has that even been done? Or is this choice (Copenhagen or Many worlds interpretation) just a matter of aesthetics, i.e. which interpretation suits you better?

PS: If you stop to think about it, on either interpretation, the measurement depends on your actual conscience. In the Copenhagen interpretation, you "modify" the wave function by measuring it, but on the Many Worlds interpretation, once you know the measurement, you know exactly in which universe you are, so you "modified"  or "collapsed" your universe.

snippet.textDisplay: My disbelief in the many worlds theory was always tied to the conservation of energy, energy can't exist out of nothingness, well, expept those pesky zero point fluctuations that we have no idea what causes them. But since energy is divided, then does this mean our universe drops into lower and lower energy states just because time passes and universes diverge?

snippet.textDisplay:
I like to think that branching does not exist in the way that there is one universe, a superposition collapses and now there are 2, i like to think of it as a completely other 5th dimension where you don't move through space or time but you move through probability, this also implies that all possible universes that will ever exist due to collapsing superpositions don't get created at the point of the collapsing super position but they have always existed parallel to each other and only started to divert at the point the superposition collapses


also it should be possible to time travel without creating a paradox by forcing the time traveler to not just move through the 4th but also though the 5th dimension, as you can't influence your own past because you are now in a different world with a different you that does not share your past.
snippet.textOriginal:
I like to think that branching does not exist in the way that there is one universe, a superposition collapses and now there are 2, i like to think of it as a completely other 5th dimension where you don't move through space or time but you move through probability, this also implies that all possible universes that will ever exist due to collapsing superpositions don't get created at the point of the collapsing super position but they have always existed parallel to each other and only started to divert at the point the superposition collapses


also it should be possible to time travel without creating a paradox by forcing the time traveler to not just move through the 4th but also though the 5th dimension, as you can't influence your own past because you are now in a different world with a different you that does not share your past.

snippet.textDisplay:
I am aware of the uncertainty principle, but I always thought of it to mean that those types of properties (like position and momentum) simply don't exist with such certainties at that small of a scale. Or, put in another way, our ways of describing "exact" position and momentum at out familiar macroscopic model are really the approximations, but the way we describe them as probabilities at the QM level are the "real" way to describe them.


Anyway, I feel like the kind of argument made in this video is fundamentally flawed. The point of probabilities isn't to have "many worlds" -- probabilities are there just to have a convenient description of the "likelihood" of an event that would be hard (or even impossible, like in the above scenario) for us to know beforehand. For ex, if I flip a coin in the air, we say it has a 50% chance of being either heads or tails. However, if you measure the exact conditions right when I flip the coin, you can know the outcome before it lands. Even though we cannot measure QM in the same way, this fact does not mean that there isn't a set path those particles take. I'd like to think that if I travel back in time and play reality back in the exact same way as before I arrived back in time, then I will get the exact same outcome. Is this thought experiment flawed?
snippet.textOriginal:

Or, put in another way, our ways of describing "exact" position and momentum at out familiar macroscopic model are really the approximations, but the way we describe them as probabilities at the QM level are the "real" way to describe them.


Anyway, I feel like the kind of argument made in this video is fundamentally flawed.  The point of probabilities isn't to have "many worlds" -- probabilities are there just to have a convenient description of the "likelihood" of an event that would be hard (or even impossible, like in the above scenario) for us to know beforehand.  For ex, if I flip a coin in the air, we say it has a 50% chance of being either heads or tails.  However, if you measure the exact conditions right when I flip the coin, you can know the outcome before it lands.  Even though we cannot measure QM in the same way, this fact does not mean that there isn't a set path those particles take.  I'd like to think that if I travel back in time and play reality back in the exact same way as before I arrived back in time, then I will get the exact same outcome.  Is this thought experiment flawed?

snippet.textDisplay: Ever since i saw the double slit experiment video (the one with the cheesy 3d einstein) on youtube as child ive always said that the universe or energy does what it wants when we not looking. I always thought that because light travels so fast to our eyes that things would literally appear before us based on what we perceive reality to be. Our eyesight is the measuring device and thus the universe follows  schrodingers law. It also makes me think that the universe shows cats, dogs and small children things that they would never show us because cats dogs and small children cannot observe and comprehend like an adult can.

snippet.textDisplay: Asserting there are infinite copies of “you” but “you” aren’t experiencing or perceiving it because it’s not “you” is a complete contradiction.  If it’s not the same atoms, then it’s not you.  An identical copy would not be another you, it’d be a clone but very much someone else.  Also where does all this matter and energy come from to create this infinite amount of multiverses?  Or they do not contain any matter or energy, therefore do not exist? Maybe this is why Einstein accused Schrodinger of mysticism...
snippet.textOriginal: Asserting there are infinite copies of “you” but “you” aren’t experiencing or perceiving it because it’s not “you” is a complete contradiction.  If it’s not the same atoms, then it’s not you.  An identical copy would not be another you, it’d be a clone but very much someone else.  Also where does all this matter and energy come from to create this infinite amount of multiverses?  Or they do not contain any matter or energy, therefore do not exist? Maybe this is why Einstein accused Schrodinger of mysticism...

snippet.textDisplay:
Okay, so I think this theory is kiiiinda bs. On the 10th minute mark the logic kind of fades from. I'm not a STEM student, so feel free to correct me. And not a natural English speaker, so feel free to correct me even more!
So lets get to the point. So, when we see the system as a whole it is logically entangled within FUNCTION of it. When you look at it you measure it, but you do not become the end of the system YOU as an individual look at it, your atoms of as a human are not the part of this system, even if you think as a part of the experiment it is a way to solve the dyllema by actually getting the new idea into it though breaking the blade of Okama rule. And the mere perception of an experiment doesn't grant you the function equal to the part of the experiment. The dylema is representing the abstraction we go through to ease the process of calculating something as a wave opposite to trying to perceive something as a particle, but it doesn't mean it was meant to humour the idea of it, rather to show the thought process.
So yeah, and the last thing, our brain is actually quite dumb and it doesn't get a lot information about the REAL world per se, but to actually ignore other realities would be quite impossible to not catch for it and if it would, it may just blow up.
Also, for this to happen, either any particle with wave characteristics may create other realities at whim of an allmighty perciever, which is imho quite scaary. But to entangle ourselves with a particle or particles that have such possilities be impossible because we are, you know, quite fixated as "waves"… we are not isotopes that can be in a superposition.

snippet.textDisplay:
Okey, so lets step back a bit and think of the following:
Suppose the universe is infinite and we have Schrödinger‘s equation suggesting that there are probably infinite parallel branches of alternative universes, shouldn‘t it be possible then, that our observations and all our deducted equations could have an alternate form in an alternate branch? And if so, what if those equations in a different branch then suggest a different logic then the many worlds thought tries to express? Wouldn‘t that be a contradiction to our model of how the universe evolves? Any thoughts on that?
snippet.textOriginal:
Okey, so lets step back a bit and think of the following:
Suppose the universe is infinite and we have Schrödinger‘s equation suggesting that there are probably infinite parallel branches of alternative universes, shouldn‘t it be possible then, that our observations and all our deducted equations could have an alternate form in an alternate branch? And if so, what if those equations in a different branch then suggest a different logic then the many worlds thought tries to express? Wouldn‘t that be a contradiction to our model of how the universe evolves? Any thoughts on that?

snippet.textDisplay: Derek, a very important question that you did not answer in the video. If the entirety of reality is in some kind of superposition, and our world is just a slice of it, how can there be a countable number of worlds? snippet.textDisplay: Experimental verification of the branching seems possible, because the branches aren't perfectly isolated from one another, it's just that their average impact on one another is zero--they're incoherent, each pulling in a random direction, and the average sum of all those random interactions is zero.  Devices like quantum computers are engineered to maintain coherent superposition, sticking with pure Schrodinger for as long as possible.  So a sufficiently advanced device might be able to isolate a particular branch and exchange information with it!
snippet.textOriginal: Experimental verification of the branching seems possible, because the branches aren't perfectly isolated from one another, it's just that their average impact on one another is zero--they're incoherent, each pulling in a random direction, and the average sum of all those random interactions is zero.  Devices like quantum computers are engineered to maintain coherent superposition, sticking with pure Schrodinger for as long as possible.  So a sufficiently advanced device might be able to isolate a particular branch and exchange information with it!

snippet.textDisplay:
I'd like to mention one thought, that I find to be an argument against the branching idea.


Before you proceed, please, note: I'm not a physicist myself and do not understand completely the math behind the wave function. I had only a course at my university, where I've got the basics of it. Therefore: a) I will most likely use the term "decay" in a wrong manner (I will mean something, that is likely to happen only once over a great period of time, but certainly can at any given moment); b) the below-described idea is based only on understanding the way probability itself works; c) there may and with a high probability exist some moment, which after being corrected slays all the below idea.


SO!


In this video, there's a mention, that you've got a lot of decays in your body, which by your extension cause the universe to "split". A human, including all the complexity of, for example, our brain, can be almost precisely considered to be a chaotic system (there was a mention of this in "What Is NOT Random" video). This means, that any tiny change in the initial conditions can potentially change the behavior of the system dramatically. The decay in our brain is an example of such a change. It does not mean each one simple decay of course, but that means with a high probability most of the combinations of decays at least periodically. And those will most likely drive people crazy rather than turn him\her into a president.


Now, let's take into consideration the branching idea. As of it, the current version of the universe, even if it exists for only a while, is one of * some really really great number* universes. For the sake of simplicity, let's also assume, that branching happens only with decays within humans. This, including the number of people and an average number of decays per second, is still billions of, perhaps, billions of branches per day.


And here is the point: what we observe most of the time is normal. Completely. Most of the time most of the people behave in a normal explainable manner. Even if they do weird stuff, most of the time we can explain their actions because of the determinism of human-scale objects.


What I mean, is that if a human is a chaotic system with thousands of decays per day and that if each decay creates a new universe, where the decay had its influence or not, then there is a high chance, that over time most of the versions will have most or at least a lot (depending on the above-stated period) of the people crazy, since the chance of getting the decay (or, again, a combination of decays) that will have great influence on their behavior is constantly increasing.


This may not seem to be intuitive since most of us exist for a very long time and we are certainly not crazy now. But, in our universe, not each possible decay certainly happens, while in all the branches they do. Of course, there's still a place for "despite that has very-very-very low probability, it still can happen and we can be just lucky". But this is really unlikely to happen, so I omit this case.


I do understand, that there are a lot of things, that are based on my feelings. Like the probability of most of the combinations of decays to drive you crazy. But still, in my opinion, if the branching idea is true, what we should observe, that over time people are going crazy.


If we also roll back our simplifications, not only humans but most of the things will over time go crazy.

For the sake of simplicity, let's also assume, that branching happens only with decays within humans. This, including the number of people and an average number of decays per second, is still billions of, perhaps, billions of branches per day. 


And here is the point: what we observe most of the time is normal. Completely. Most of the time most of the people behave in a normal explainable manner. Even if they do weird stuff, most of the time we can explain their actions because of the determinism of human-scale objects.


What I mean, is that if a human is a chaotic system with thousands of decays per day and that if each decay creates a new universe, where the decay had its influence or not,  then there is a high chance, that over time most of the versions will have most or at least a lot (depending on the above-stated period) of the people crazy, since the chance of getting the decay (or, again, a combination of decays) that will have great influence on their behavior is constantly increasing.


This may not seem to be intuitive since most of us exist for a very long time and we are certainly not crazy now. But, in our universe, not each possible decay certainly happens, while in all the branches they do. Of course, there's still a place for "despite that has very-very-very low probability, it still can happen and we can be just lucky". But this is really unlikely to happen, so I omit this case.


I do understand, that there are a lot of things, that are based on my feelings. Like the probability of most of the combinations of decays to drive you crazy. But still, in my opinion, if the branching idea is true, what we should observe, that over time people are going crazy.


If we also roll back our simplifications, not only humans but most of the things will over time go crazy.

snippet.textDisplay:
I never see anyone talk about the fact that many worlds might be the least parsimonious theory ever put forward. Plenty of quantum theories require weird assumptions, but many worlds requires unlimited extra universes that we have no direct evidence of.


If someone had a theory that involved them being right... as long as you granted them ONE extra universe they would be laughed at. But somehow this theory that needs the maximum number of extra universes gets a pass because it somehow makes more sense to the human mind than wave functions collapsing.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: So, I take issue simply with the conservation of mass and energy. How could there be these splits if mass and energy must remain constant? Would this break this rule? Or do the splits now each carry a fraction of the mass and energy equal to the probability of that event occurring? And if this is the case, then does that mean that there's an endpoint, where the mass and energy is completely abd evenly spread out among a very large but finite number of splits? This is of course assuming the total mass and energy of the universe is finite. I have so many more questions about the implications of this.

snippet.textDisplay: I've wondered how quantum mechanics applies to the sport of football. When a quarterback throws a pass there are just probabilities that the receiver will or won't catch the ball. Then, depending on the catch or miss, a new reality is imposed on the game, which will create other probabilities and realities. I've sometimes wondered how the call of the play affects the course of the game. Will a quarterback throw a hook pass, or a flare pass, on the next play, with the attendant outcomes of probability and certainty? I don't know. This is just idle speculation. Also, there is the outcome of the entire game. Will a disgruntled fan beat his wife because his team lost?

snippet.textDisplay:
If the "universe split" effect travels outward from a quantum event at the speed of light, could you build an experiment that places an observer in such a way that they might experience a noticeable (if subjective) contradictory effect? Say you took that atom of radium and had two detectors equidistant from it. If the atom decays, each detector shines a laser into one of the observer's eyes (left detector to left eye, right detector to right eye). Each detector would measure the atom as its own distinct event, and either shine the light or not. Couldn't this render each eye a separate observer to the event? And potentially render different parts of one human brain as separate observers, as well (where "left brain" and "right brain" experience incompatible outcomes)?


Even if there is some physical mechanism that prevents one detector from registering mutually contradictory outcomes, the brain isn't just one detector. It seems to me that you could end up where the brain's overall perception is juggling four potential outcomes: two where the lasers agree, and two where they disagree.


Obviously, there is only one "real" answer, as that person can then check the atom and determine what the outcome of the experiment was, so the observer may only be getting something like a perceptual glimpse of that alternate reality (or maybe that universe only exists as an unrealized reality, like a shadow or an illusion as the person's continued investigation of the world reflects the results of only one outcome). Whether that glimpse was of something real or not has no effect on anything. We're still in a Copenhagen-friendly observable universe, with the only wrinkle being a momentary impression of incongruity.
snippet.textOriginal:
If the "universe split" effect travels outward from a quantum event at the speed of light, could you build an experiment that places an observer in such a way that they might experience a noticeable (if subjective) contradictory effect?  Say you took that atom of radium and had two detectors equidistant from it.  If the atom decays, each detector shines a laser into one of the observer's eyes (left detector to left eye, right detector to right eye).  Each detector would measure the atom as its own distinct event, and either shine the light or not.  Couldn't this render each eye a separate observer to the event?  And potentially render different parts of one human brain as separate observers, as well (where "left brain" and "right brain" experience incompatible outcomes)?


Even if there is some physical mechanism that prevents one detector from registering mutually contradictory outcomes, the brain isn't just one detector.  It seems to me that you could end up where the brain's overall perception is juggling four potential outcomes: two where the lasers agree, and two where they disagree.


Obviously, there is only one "real" answer, as that person can then check the atom and determine what the outcome of the experiment was, so the observer may only be getting something like a perceptual glimpse of that alternate reality (or maybe that universe only exists as an unrealized reality, like a shadow or an illusion as the person's continued investigation of the world reflects the results of only one outcome).  Whether that glimpse was of something real or not has no effect on anything.  We're still in a Copenhagen-friendly observable universe, with the only wrinkle being a momentary impression of incongruity.

snippet.textDisplay: "The air molecules bouncing created a separate, parallel world." LOL
snippet.textOriginal: "The air molecules bouncing created a separate, parallel world." LOL

snippet.textDisplay: Ok what am I missing?  Why do quantum physicists get to claim proof of multiple realities whenever they measure something?  Is the proof supposed to be that they changed the trajectory (or state, or whatever) of the particle by measuring it?  Interacting with something in order to measure it doesn't seem unusual to me.  Like, a psychologist has to interact with a person to gauge their mood.  "How are you feeling?"  Maybe they were feeling fine until you asked them that --> now they're questioning themselves.  Boom, interaction.  You usually have to interact with something to measure it, I believe, thus changing it's course in space and time to some degree.  Why explain this with multiple simultaneous universes?
snippet.textOriginal: Ok what am I missing?  Why do quantum physicists get to claim proof of multiple realities whenever they measure something?  Is the proof supposed to be that they changed the trajectory (or state, or whatever) of the particle by measuring it?  Interacting with something in order to measure it doesn't seem unusual to me.  Like, a psychologist has to interact with a person to gauge their mood.  "How are you feeling?"  Maybe they were feeling fine until you asked them that --> now they're questioning themselves.  Boom, interaction.  You usually have to interact with something to measure it, I believe, thus changing it's course in space and time to some degree.  Why explain this with multiple simultaneous universes?

snippet.textDisplay:
"It's not that quantum physics is wrong about superposition, it's that what didn't happen, actually happened in a parallel world."
This is why people laugh at scientists. What an absolute joke this is. What complete cognitive dissonance.
